unit_learning_outcomes.description: Demonstrate an advanced understanding of legal principles relating to national or international law and critically apply your legal knowledge to resolve complex legal questions through oral and written presentations.
Actively work as part of a team to develop a cohesive team argument, and contribute to fostering an ethical and responsible working environment.
Demonstrate an enquiring, critical, analytical and thoughtful approach to advocacy and procedure before the Court.
Formulate, present and evaluate oral and written arguments, drawing on precedent and policy considerations in the relevant field of national or international law and practice.

enrolment_rules.description: Admission to JD and 80cp in LAWS or LAW units at 6000 level or above and Permission by Special Approval

assessments.description: Students will be required to submit Written Memorials that comply with the official rules of the competition moot. The team must prepare and submit one Applicant and one Respondent memorial. These will be constructed as a team.

Students will be assessed on their ability to present oral arguments in mock trials and court appearances and assessed both in terms of comparison to individual submission of preparatory work and through peer assessment

data.unit_offering_text:
Session 3, Infrequent attendance, North Ryde*

* This unit offering is subject to a quota. Limited places are available. Please refer to the Faculty for further information.
data.description: This unit is to provide select JD students with the opportunity to be involved in competitive national and international mooting competitions. Offers for particular moots may vary year to year dependent on the availability and expertise of coaching staff. It may include for instance the Jessup International Law Moot Court Competition that is held each year and involves teams from around the world. An Australian regional round of competition is held annually in Canberra during February and from which the Australian representatives are selected to compete in the international round in Washington (USA), usually in the following April. Students in this unit work as a team in preparing written memorials in relation to a problem set by the competition organisers. The problems raise issues of current interest in the field of international law.
data.title: Law Moots and Competitions

title: Law Moots and Competitions
